summary: When Elinor Dashwood's (Emma Thompson) father dies, her family's finances are crippled. After the Dashwoods move to a cottage in Devonshire, Elinor's sister Marianne (Kate Winslet) is torn between the handsome John Willoughby (Greg Wise) and the older Colonel Brandon (Alan Rickman). Meanwhile, Elinor's romantic hopes with Edward Ferrars (Hugh Grant) are hindered due to his prior engagement. Both Elinor and Marianne strive for love while the circumstances in their lives constantly change.

reviews.content: Best Austen adaptation to date.

Sense and Sensibility" is a 1995 period drama film directed by Ang Lee, based on the novel of the same name by Jane Austen. The film features an all-star cast, including Emma Thompson, Kate Winslet, Hugh Grant, and Alan Rickman, and was a critical and commercial success upon its release.
The film tells the story of the Dashwood sisters, Elinor (Thompson) and Marianne (Winslet), who are left in financial dire straits after their father dies and their half-brother inherits the family estate. Forced to move to a cottage in the countryside, the sisters navigate the tricky waters of love and society as they attempt to find suitable husbands.
Thompson, who also wrote the screenplay, delivers a nuanced and heartfelt performance as Elinor, the sensible and pragmatic sister who struggles to reconcile her feelings for the reserved and honorable Edward Ferrars (Grant). Winslet is equally impressive as Marianne, the impulsive and romantic sister who falls for the dashing and charismatic John Willoughby (Greg Wise), only to learn the harsh realities of love and class.Lee's direction is elegant and restrained, capturing the beauty and grace of the English countryside while also emphasizing the emotional undercurrents of the story. The supporting cast is excellent as well, with Rickman delivering a memorable turn as the brooding and conflicted Colonel Brandon.
The target audience of the film "Sense and Sensibility" is primarily adult viewers who enjoy period dramas, romance, and literary adaptations. The film's themes and characters will likely appeal to viewers who appreciate Austen's writing and the Regency era in which the story is set. The film's tone and pacing are more measured and deliberate than modern-day action or blockbuster films, making it more suitable for those who enjoy a slower, character-driven story.
According to the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the film has an approval rating of 98% based on 52 reviews, with an average rating of 8.8/10. The film also received positive reviews from audiences and was a commercial success, grossing over $134 million worldwide against a budget of $16.5 million.
Overall, "Sense and Sensibility" is a beautifully crafted and emotionally resonant film that captures the wit, wisdom, and romance of Jane Austen's classic novel. With its stellar performances, stunning cinematography, and impeccable production design, it is a true cinematic gem that is not to be missed.
Time passes quickly as if you are in the airy mist which seems to have influenced the cinematography.The screen ensemble knows you are there with them.

Emma Thompson has better chemistry with Alan Rickman than with Hugh Grant. Given the sizable age gap between Kate Winslet and Professor Snape, I found myself expecting Snape to end up with Professor Trelawney by the end but nope. And don't give me "it happened in the book" as a counter-argument, there was a more respectable age difference in the Jane Austen novel. That nitpick aside, Sense & Sensibility is a really good period piece/romantic drama with great performances & cinematography, a riveting script that gave Emma Thompson an unusual Oscar combination for Best Actress & Best Adapted Screenplay and Ang Lee's direction helping the film stay true to the novel while still updating it in such a way that it appeals to changing, *ahem*, sensibilities of the late '90s. I don't think this is quite as compelling or witty as Pride & Prejudice but this is still excellent filmmaking in its own right.
P.S. Is it just me or is this the only one of Jane Austen's holy trinity of novels - Pride and Prejudice, Sense & Sensibility and Emma - that didn't get a 21st-century retelling? Maybe we should do that, provided we have the right filmmakers to avoid the usual nonsense that results in such lovely words as "woke", a term which I will *never* use unironically, regardless of my opinion on the media's quality.
One of the most perfect films ever concocted.  Never artsy or pretentious, this is a blast of entertainment from start to finish.

Oh my gosh, where do I start? This is beautifully shot, beautifully adapted to the big screen, and (I know, I know, it's sacrilege), I almost prefer it to the book. I watch this movie all the time, and if you like Jane Austen or Regency era England, this is definitely for you. My husband even loves this film. This is a visually stunning masterpiece, and only the likes of Ang Lee and Emma Thompson could have brought this story to life like this. Seriously good.
Excellent adaptation. Cast is uniformally excellent, albeit age gaps stretch credulity a bit.
Beautifully mesmerising, absolutely terrific movie!
Absolutely brilliant adaptation of Austen's novel.  Perfectly cast, perfectly written.  Beautiful film from start to finish, with a blend of humor and romance.

I love Jane Austen, and I love period dramas. This film, while a little too long, was perfect for me. I loved it when I first saw it a year ago, and I still love it now. Sense and Sensibility is a great book by Miss Austen, and this film does the book justice, in my personal opinion. The film looks gorgeous, the camera-work, the locations and the costumes. The script sparkled with wit, subtlety, romance and heartache, especially when Marianne goes out into the rain and gets herself ill. The music is lovely also. The performances were exceptional. Period-film veteran Emma Thompson is lovely here as Elinor Dashwood, and Kate Winslet matches her perfectly in a beautifully-blended portrayal of the tragic Marianne. As for the men, they were very good too. Hugh Grant was exceedingly charming as the male lead, and I have read many reviews criticising Alan Rickman's acting.(not on IMDb though) He may have been older than Miss Austen intended, he was very good also as Colonel Brandon, but not as good as the other three. His style of acting is very suave and charismatic, like Sean Connery and George Sanders. If you've seen him in Robin Hood:Prince of Thieves you'll know what I mean. All in all, a lovely film, maybe not the best period drama, but has plenty of elements that makes it truly memorable. 9/10 Bethany Cox
Thank you Jane Austen and Emma Thompson too. Fantastic, romantic, funny and wonderful!
A plausible adaptation of the Jane Austen novel. Possibly for Austen fans only.

As expected, it is full with gentlemen and elegant women. The thing that I found particularly interesting was the absence of characters with pure evil drives because these types of stories often involve such characters with bad manners who ruin everything. Every single character in the movie seems to have a good being and their cruel thoughts were understandable when we look at from their perspectives. After all, the movie is based on a Jane Austin novel and you can clearly see the elements of a Jane Austin story.
A charmingly witty and moving tale of two sisters and their suitors, "Sense and Sensibility" is a beautiful, impeccably-acted film adaptation of Jane Austen's first novel.

While the lead actors are all talented, most of them felt stragely cast.  But most off all   I miss the subtle yet tangable tention that Jane Austen usually provides. To build this tention, I feel you must take your time to get to know the caracters and there nuances, or leave them out. Adhere to the social rules, language and behavior of the time or break away from them completely. Here it was a mix of both worlds that, at least for me, did not work.

I don’t understand why this is so well-reviewed and well-rated. Having recently watched Pride and Prejudice, and Jane Eyre, this is the most bland and silly adaptation of those 19th century novels. I don’t remember my impressions when I read this as a teenager, but I’m disappointed in Ang Lee - even the score is excessively melodramatic and often gives away the absurd “surprise” that is about to come. Mediocre at best.

Big standard English period drama where a bunch of romantically angst driven women whose whole lives revolve around obsessive behaviour towards men, live through drama about non events. The audience is meant to care and credulously believe the preposterous ending. Emma Thompson acts well, Hugh Grant is infuriatingly irritating throughout.

It's incredible how Emma Thompson managed to include so much information from the book in very effective scenes, and yet deliver a powerful subtext within every dialog between all the characters. That's British diplomacy paying off.
it's one of my all time favorite movies

Ang Lee's only period piece and Jane Austen adaptation at the height of several movies made from the 1800 novels during the 1990s.
I remember watching it years back but fully appreciate it balanced nuance and creativity.
Top notch cast with Emma Thompson, Hugh Grant, Kate Winslet, and the late Alan Rickman 
Still a very sweet and humorous adaptation. 
The novel actually linked to WWI soldiers in distressing times, they were actually prescribed to relieve many from shell shock. So like the movie it's based on it offers a sweet, funny take on love, decorum, and passion.
Even Emma Thompson took on the daring task of writing the screenplay,  even gave voices to frustrations of women during this time period when it came to property laws and the marriage market. There's a lot of good constructive criticism on these injustices. 
One of the best Jane Austen adaptations I have to say.
Dull and overly self-conscious at times, but its sticking to a course without wandering here and there carries it through.
Nice visualy, charming cast, with slow plot, but very beautiful and emotional movie.

What weakness there is in this adaptation of Sense and Sensibility has to do largely with the source material - melodrama doesn't necessarily become classic or better composed just because it has some age to it, and the narrative is still about love triangles and marriage prospects in high society England, at the end of the day. Still, the film does a marvelous job at creating dialogue, atmosphere, and performances that do away with much of the stuffy pretentiousness associated with an Austen novel and instead provide a legitimately endearing, funny, and relatable period romance. Castings here made the careers of many of its young stars, and added to many more, with Thompson, Winslet, Rickman, and Grant all providing excellent characterizations, and some of the supporting roles feeling just as substantial (particularly Spriggs as the boisterous Mrs. Jennings and Laurie cast out of type as the taciturn Mr. Palmer). Production quality is uniformly solid, and the film itself holds up to modern standards and should be enjoyed for decades to come. Completely changed what classic 19th century British literature could be adapted to in film; David Lean no longer reigned without equal, the director/screenwriter team of Lee and Thompson proving fit for the task. (4/5)

Ang Lee's "Sense and Sensibility" is a gorgeous, moving and sublime period piece that offers a fresh interpretation of Jane Austen's classic novel. With his fourth feature, director Ang Lee crafted an astonishing adaptation of Jane Austen's book that holds up today as a modern classic. Using sumptuous cinematography, Lee draws viewers into the world of two sisters searching for love in the 19th Century. From intimate close-ups to gorgeous establishing shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's historical setting. The sets, costumes and musical score are all carefully chosen, combining to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. It is hard to not admire the astonishing performances from the cast. Emma Thompson delivers one of the best performances of her career as Elinor Dashwood. With mesmerizing expressions, she conveys the innocence, exuberance and free-spirited persona of the classic literary character. Kate Winslet is equally appealing in the role of a feisty woman searching for love. In one of her first lead roles, Winslet proves to be a star in the making. The supporting cast, which includes the hilarious Hugh Grant, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "Sense and Sensibility" is undeniably unforgettable, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At over two hours, it is slightly long and suffers from a drawn-out running-time. Nevertheless, fans of Jane Austen will definitely enjoy "Sense and Sensibility" and so will movie-goers seeking old-fashioned entertainment. At a time when modern audiences have never heard of Jane Austen, it's a stirring reminder that her timeless stories are worth retelling on the big-screen.
best Jane Austen movie. lovely story.

In the time of Jane Austen's Sense and Sensibility, marriage is, as one of the Dashwood sisters laments late in the film, a decision between the demands of the pocketbook or the demands of the heart.  Apropos to this, Elinor and Marianne (Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet, respectively) are bound by the strict rules concerning courtship. They suffer and rejoice accordingly.  Ang Lee's film was nominated for numerous Oscars and won the Golden Globe for Best Picture.  The acting is uniformly sound, the cinematography is great, and the writing is excellent.  While it may be a bit overhyped critically, it's still an enjoyable viewing experience.

An absolute delight! "Sense and Sensibility" has it all - fantastic acting, witty dialogue, great costumes, stunning sets and scenery and a wonderful mix of charm, comedy, pathos and real heart. Ang Lee's directing exceeds all expectations! And the leads of Emma Thompson, Kate Winslet and Alan Rickman are all in top form. The one detraction is Hugh Grant as a bit too insipid for the role of Edward Ferrars. It's all rounded out by some of the great stars of Brit film in secondary roles such as Imelda Staunton, Tom Hardy, Hugh Laurie (looking so dashing!) and Harriet Walters in a deliciously wicked performance as the wicked sister-in-law. A classic!

The movie is visually astonishing;  every actor is a brilliant casting choice and resembles perfectly the role except Thompson who (being also the screenwriter) deviates from the original character to have a more dramatic vibe, and all of the movie misses that subtleness that made Austen's novels so brilliant
One of my favorite books made into a fantastic film, that is witty and well acted.
A lovely adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved novel by Ang Lee. What is not to like about that?

An enduring classic that's lovingly and truly adapted from the classic Jane Austen novel. Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet are perfect as dutiful, reserved Elinor and passionate, unrestrained Marianne respectively. In fact, the entire cast is perfect - Hugh Grant, Alan Rickman, Greg Wise, Gemma Jones, Imelda Staunton, Hugh Laurie, Harriet Walter, and Elizabeth Spriggs -  I can't imagine anyone else in these roles. Ang Lee did a beautiful job highlighting the yearning, loneliness, desperation, hopefulness, and disappointments of women of this time and it makes it very palpable for modern viewers. Which is why I don't mind that Thompson is a bit old for Elinor, because would a modern audience understand she's pretty much an old maid at 19? There's a few other liberties with the story and I support all of them, but Austen's story of love and sisterhood is still wholly evident. Beautiful sets, cinematography, and the score is achingly beautiful. This is epically rewatchable and I cry every time.

Director Ang Lee's first English-speaking film boasts a stellar cast who all give fine performances and an involving story that is wonderfully written by lead actress Emma Thompson. An utter pleasure to watch.
Excellent film. Very good casting of Kate Winslet and Emma Thompson. Sharp and funny script. For a Jane Austen adaptation, it was pretty good.
Enjoyable characters to follow.

Ageless and classic! The actors did such an amazing job with this I could have watched hours more. Wonderful costumes and sets, great delivery of storyline, you end up so invested in what happens. This will remain one of those movies you hope they don't remake because they got it right.

This is the movie that made me discover my favourite author. I might be bias, love all the actors and how they interpret their characters, love the well executed period wardrobe of this movie. This has become over the years into my "Feel Good" Regency movie.

Sense and Sensibility is arguably one of the best movies I've seen. Created in 1995 by Ang Lee and based on Jane Austen's novel with the same name, we follow the story of a family from Norland who go through a lot, to say the least. The family consists of a father, mother and 3 daughters. A traditional family you would think but, let's dive into the less pleasant stuff the family Dashwood has been through.
The movie is about the Dashwood family consisting of a father, mother and their three daughters: Marianne, Elinore and Margarette who were happily living in their country house in Norland until the father dies. The father leaves everything to his son John. He was the son of his other wife. The father asked John to promise that he will help his wife and children. John did indeed promise he would help them but after his death, John's wife, called Fanny, manipulates him and he ends up not helping the Dashwood ladies.
The ladies are forced to move out. In the meantime, when the Dashwood ladies are in the country house in Norland, Edward Ferras, who is John's brother in law, comes for a visit. He and Elinor seem to like each other but Edwards sister doesn't allow their bond to develop any further so the Dashwood ladies move into their new house. When Marianne sprains her ankle while walking with her sister, she meets Willoughby, she immediately feels attracted to him. He helps her and brings her home. Mr. Willoughby seems to be interested in Marianne and they spend a lot of time together. Everyone is convinced that they are planning to eventually get married, but then they go to London and everything gets out of hand.
 I really liked the story because it wasn't a typical love story as you see in every romantic movie these days. The movie has a lot of scenes that make you think deeply and teach you a lot about life. I feel like I look differently at some things in life after watching this movie. The movie is played very immersivly, sometimes it felt like I was truly in the movie. 
My favorite scene would have to be the one where Edward kindheartedly wipes the tears off of the crying Elinor with his handkerchief and allows her to keep it. I guess you could say it's because I appreciate the gesture of love but there's more to it than that, at least in my eyes. It symbolizes one of the few times something goes right for the Dashwood family and also reminded Elinor never to be too gloomy because she'd always look at his handkerchief whenever she'd want to reminisce. So it's not only a beautiful gesture of their mutual affection, but also a symbol of things yet to come.
The characters were also completely different from the stereotypes we have nowadays. For example Elinor, she was the one who kept her feelings to herself and didn't tell anyone about it in contrast to Marianne who was very open about her feelings. When she felt unhappy, others would notice. My favorite character was Elinor. I really liked the way she acted, and she also fancied her personality. This is because I think we have a lot in common and sometimes I saw myself in her. Her personality really took my attention, she was the one who put aside her own sorrow and only thought about her sisters, her mother and it was very beautiful. 
To conclude, I really liked the performances of the main cast. The movie was played beautifully. Though my personal favourite would have to be Emma Thompson as Elinor. She knew just how to pull one's heartstrings and make me feel sad, happy or whatever was required from her. For a movie filmed in 1995 I honestly think the camera work amazingly good, people often underestimate how crucial that is to a movie. The music didn't lack behind either and really made sure it felt like a cohesive experience. I really liked Sense and Sensibility.
Sense and Sensibility is an undeniable Jane Austin masterpiece marked by a wonderful love story brought to film with Emma Thompson's masterfully winning performance.

Great, funny, dramatic and entertaining movie. Ang Lee is a great director and this is certainly one of his best movies. I don't usually cry during a movie, but during the emotional climax I noticed that I had some tears rolling on my cheeks. Great acting by everyone but especially by Emma Thompson who also wrote the screenplay.
Emma Thompson is such a charmer in this film. Ang Lee takes on a classic British period drama. The sheer audacity of him to take the challenge, really established himself as truly of one the great.

I enjoyed the cold, detached approach that Ang Lee brought to The Ice Storm (1997), a story about very privileged, dislikable people who face a tragedy, but when I watch an adaptation of a Jane Austen novel I want to see someone who loves the characters. Whit Stilman's Love and Friendship (2016) is probably my favorite Austen film but obviously I am not expecting a film as big as Sense and Sensibility to contain all of the idiosyncrasies of an independent film. I don't like Kate Winslet, I've made that perfectly clear in my Titanic (1997) review, and I felt that she was terrible here and she almost ruined the film as a whole. If you want to see a really good, mainstream Jane Austen adaptation watch Pride and Prejudice (2005) before you even consider going near this.

Elinor, Emma Thompson, and Marianne, Kate Winslet, are kicked out of their house and lose their significant fortune after the death of their father as their older brother and his wife take control. They are forced to search for financial security in the form of husbands after this and while Elinor quietly pines for Edward Ferrars, Hugh Grant, who she expects will not marry her because she is poor. Colonel Brandon, Alan Rickman, is an older man who is in love with Marianne who herself loves the unreliable John Willoughby, Greg Wise. The two very different sisters will eventually find love with the right men and learn to lean on one another.

The utterly lovable Emma Thompson makes the film worthwhile as she is the perfect Marianne, convincing in her strong principles, sensibility and quiet sadness at her lack of romantic prospects. In the scenes in which Elinor and Edward interact it becomes clear that Thompson can act circles around Grant but he is entertaining enough employing his usual charms. Conversely, Winslet is quite unconvincing as Marianne with every move she makes feeling false and her facial expressions looking the same throughout. Had Rachel Weisz been cast in the role I would be far more charmed by her character and I think the film would work better as a whole. Rickman is very good as Colonel Brandon but he's a better romantic lead in Truly, Madly, Deeply (1990). Some of the acting is great, some of it is awful much like the film itself.

The whole film in it's technical execution felt very constructed and that prevented me from really engaging with it because I could always sense Lee and those making the films and their decisions instead of becoming immersed in the world. Even the outside environments look like matte paintings and when indoor all of the people seem to be cold and stiff like frozen fish. Traditional British costume dramas that I love like The Bostonians (1984) and The Portrait of a Lady (1996) allow to feel the environments that these people live in. You can smell the sea spray and feel the cool air when you watch Vanessa Redgrave and Madeleine Potter argue in The Bostonians. I wanted that here but I didn't feel anything viscerally during this film and I may as well have been sitting in a theatre watching some RADA graduates perform around a hermetically sealed set.

I applaud Thompson for her screenplay as it is very faithful to the novel while also updating some elements of the book to make them more understandable to modern audiences. She was very good at never making this too jarring and writing the dialogue to sound period-accurate while not being as confusing as Shakespeare or Ibsen. She would win the Best Adapted Screenplay Academy Award in 1996 and I would say she deserved it despite facing strong competition in Apollo 13 (1995) and Leaving Las Vegas (1995).

This is a film that I wouldn't recommend because despite Thompson's best efforts she can't save a film from awkward staging and the presence of Kate Winslet. Were Merchant Ivory Productions to have made them I think this would have a better production, more filled with life and loving of it's characters like The Remains of the Day (1993). This is a film that approaches being great but is let down by a few poor decisions but I hope we will get a better adaptation one day.
The story, the adaptation, the direction, actng... all perfect in my opinion. :)
The best, GREATEST romance movie ever made! With the best movie score ever composed!

All characters lack intuition and complexity. Poor acting, especially from Emma Thompson-her facial expressions are fake and overdone and she reacts late to everything. Boring movie with little substance. Don't know why it's rated so highly.

The first thing that needs to be mentioned in Sense and Sensibility is the cast. They have a superb mix of the best British actresses and actors. Emma Thompson is perfectly restrained as Elinor. I love how well she presents that unaffected demeanor that is considered proper in this society, but she can also make dramatic swings into tearful emotion when pushed too far. Kate Winslet is the perfect counterpoint as the impetuous Marianne. While in modern society her behavior would never be considered inappropriate, she plays it with just enough raw emotion to create a strong contrast with Thompson, so we know she’s going too far. The other performance that needs to be singled out is the perfection of Alan Rickman as Colonel Brandon. Despite his stoic behavior, you can feel the heavy baggage that he carries in every scene. The sets, locations, and costumes in Sense and Sensibility all work together to take you to that time and place. This made the dialogue and behavior of the characters feel natural and fitting instead of odd. I don’t always understand the unwritten rules that governed British society at that time, so there are certain moments where I was confused why someone was or was not doing something. This is when I was most grateful for the cast because I could always count on them to react properly in order to clue me in on the fact that someone has overstepped their bounds or behaved in an inappropriate manner. I tend to get annoyed with this type of period piece after a while because they are all so restrained, and I just want them to express what they feel. But it works as a proper representation of the novel and what I assume society looked like at that time. The story of Sense and Sensibility is a little predictable, possibly because Jane Austen has been copied countless times. Even when there are moments that were built in as a surprise, you see it coming because everyone knows who the women are supposed to end up with at the end. One of the struggles that I concerned me was the age difference in one of the potential matches. It’s the kind of thing that I struggle with in other movies, but it was addressed in the dialogue and handled in a classy way, so somehow it never bothered me after the first few minutes of that storyline. I can’t fully comprehend why I got so invested in the dilemma of whether these girls would manage to get married. It seems so archaic for the happy ending to be built on a man saving them. However, I was riveted throughout. I don’t know how much to credit to Jane Austen, and how much to Ang Lee, but I found Sense and Sensibility to be a lovely and moving film.

I haven’t read the book so I wasn’t sure what this story was about but I love the relationship that sisters Elinor and Marianne have and found myself feeling like a mixture of both of them! Both brilliantly portrayed by Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet. Oh Willoughby, a delicious Greg Wise, you certainly are dashing, but ultimately Colonel Brandon, wonderfully played by Alan Rickman absolutely captured my heart! I also really liked Hugh Grant as Edward, though his family were decidedly awful!!! A delightful film with beautiful scenery and poetic romance.

A timeless tale of family, friendship, struggles, and love. This is one of my favorite movies of all time. With Austen's storytelling, amazing acting, and relatable hardships; this film is truly a classic.
The most magical, show-stopping, heart felt adaptation that made the original Victorian novel relevant again.

Ang Lee provides beautiful scenery and some nuanced direction to a Jane Austin piece. This is a film I didn't expect to like but came away highly entertained and impressed by the restraint, craft, and subtlty in the material.

Jane Austen at her best, directed by the best, played by the best, filmed on location. While all of Jane Austen's work are clearly very famous, it is in these in no small part because of movies like this one, this one in particular. Ang Lee was still not that well known to the wider audience back in 1995, but here he is surely at his best. A classic made into an instant classic. Enjoy!

Reviewed 10.10.17.  Talk about a cast, wow. And Ang Lee before he was 'Ang Lee.' Emma Thompson leads the way, with an anchoring performance. Kate Winslet makes clear why she would soon be Oscar worthy. And how often does Alan Rickman get to shine as a good guy? I thoroughly enjoyed the escapism, and was relieved by the light touch of what surely could have been a stodgy period piece. Kudos to Thompson for pulling double duty as the screenwriter. She's in rarefied air for the high quality she brings to both roles. And although the movie wasn't earth-shattering, by any stretch, it was exceedingly pleasant. When it comes to Jane Austen pieces, that is special in its own right.
Piercing but gentle, with great attention to detail, just like Austen's writing.
A great execution of the Jane Austin novel.
Good man, Rickman. He indeed played interesting people.

A remarkable period romantic drama so good could only be the work of Jane Austen. A beautiful story depicting the 19th century England and the dramas of two likeable characters portrayed by excellent actresses. Watching all those Harry Potter actors was a plus. All the characters' marvelous accents and ellegant eloquency is a pleasure to hear. Astounding score and it should have won more Oscars and Baftas.
I loved this adaption. It was so beautifully put together, the chemistry was perfect between actors.

One of my favorites that I will watch again and again. The acting, costumes and music was superb. Harriet Walter was amazing playing greedy Fanny. Stubbs was the perfect manipulative gold digger. sprigs provided excellent comic relief as she ran through the streets with the latest gossip. It could be the best cast Austen film I've seen.
One of my favourite movies to date and I have a feeling it will always be one. A well portrayed adaptation of Jane Austen's book with very lovable characters and an enjoyable plot.
A diverse crew behind the camera makes one of the most pitch perfect British period pieces probably ever.

Jane Austen's writing is a precarious balancing act between "romantic drama" and "comedy of errors". Ang Lee masterfully adapts one of her most famous novels into this droll, poised, and arresting film. The director's tight sense of pacing is a big factor in the success of this feature, but a lot of credit is due to an excellent cast that includes Kate Winslet, Alan Rickman, Hugh Grant, Harriet Walter, Hugh Laurie, Gemma Jones,James Fleet, and Emma Thompson (who also wrote the screenplay). Jane Austen can easily become a slog when her stories are transferred to celluloid, but a murderer's row of talent makes this effort into something that succeeds admirably.

As usual for Ang Lee, the landscapes and outdoors are gorgeous.
Everything else is unwatchable, in the same way as the book of same title from Jane Austen is unreadable. Probably these things were interesting for English upper class ladies contemporary of Jane Austen. But, as I try to watch - or read - this kind of things, I can't help but thank God I live in a country where dukes, barons, earls and the like do not exist, by law.
This movie is worse than boring: it is about nothing interesting, a discussion about weather would be more interesting and deep.
Hugh Grant confirms to me to be - or having been - one of the worst and most disagreeable actor I know.

It is hard to believe anybody gets happily married in 19th century England with all the rules and customs.  Jane Austen writes interesting books, and the actors in this adaptation are very convincing.
my favourite version of this often film jane austin tale wrote a paper about it in college comparing it to the book.
wonderful, if a bit shortened (: book was more enjoyable of course .. but the acting here is great. thought the buildup of Darcy & Elinor's relationship could've been better.
The finest screen adaptation of Jane Austen, every character is perfectly portrayed; Emma Thompson's finest moment, for both the screenplay and her acting.

The acting is what really makes this movie stand out. Emma Thompson plays a very timid and reasonable young woman, and I actually liked the character she played, which is saying something when I consider how much I disliked her, prior to watching this film. Winslet was perfect for the role and she pulled it off very well, acting as an immature young girl who's looking for love at every turn. If I had one problem, it would probably be Hugh Grant as Edward, the nice and charming young man who falls for Thompson's character. Grant did good in his performance, but I felt like I've seen too many movies with him as the jerk and womanizer to be taken seriously in this. It's not a huge problem, but a problem regardless. 

Rickman as the quiet and non-villain gave a great performance as you don't usually see him in this kind of role. He's usually the villain or portrayed as the villain. But, here, he gives calm and easy to follow and enjoy performance. Another problem, however, is the way the movie ends. 

I know that's how it ends in the book, but hear me out. I didn't like how little chemistry Winslet's and Rickman's characters got out of each other. Yeah, they marry in the end and it's cute, but they only share like 2 scenes where they clearly are in love. "Sense and Sensibility" is a well-executed adaptation of Jane Austin's first published novel.  Between the stunning scenery, perfect casting, and director Ang Lee's delicate treatment of the story, Elinor and Marianne Dashwood step right off of the page and into our hearts.  As one might expect, the film moves a little slow but the story is so addictive that you won't mind.  The atmosphere of the English countryside is magic and the indoor shots of high class homes have a true transporting power; however, the true power of this story comes from unexpected surprises and the need to know what happens next.  Emma Thompson is stunning as Elinor and it is easy to see why she received four Oscar nominations in the early 90's.  On top of her Best Actress nomination for this role, she won the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay.  She is perfectly matched with Kate Winslet, who earned a Best Supporting Actress nomination.  This was only Winslet's second feature film role but it is easy to see the natural acting ability that has enabled her to be a significant presence in the film industry.  These leading ladies deliver the rich dialogue in a flowing manner that makes it as beautiful to hear as it is to comprehend.  The supporting characters are also well-cast, from the deep voice of Alan Rickman (Colonel Brandon) and the good looks of Greg Wise (Willoughby) to the character acting of Imelda Staunton (Charlotte) and a young Hugh Laurie.  I did not care for Hugh Grant at first, but his delivery of Edward's final dialogue brought a tear to my eye.  I wouldn't call myself a Jane Austin fan but this rendition of "Sense and Sensibility" has inspired me to look deeper into her world and experience more of her stories.

"Sense and Sensibility" is a long period drama that might have been more suited to a miniseries, but it's pretty great as a film as well. A nice, inoffensive historical piece about 2 sisters (played by Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet, both deservedly Oscar nominated) who go through trials and tribulations and loves and losses after they're forced to move out of the lavish house they grew up in. The cast is rounded out by dozens of great supporting performances, with Hugh Grant, Alan Rickman, Greg Wise, Imelda Staunton, Hugh Laurie, Myriam Francois-Serrah, James Fleet, Elizabeth Spriggs, Gemma Jones, Harriet Walter and Imogen Stubbs all giving some of their best work. Ang Lee's direction is pretty much perfect, working with cinematographer Michael Coulter to capture the beauty of the British countryside and the city of London, though it's of course limited to the richer, more privileged lifestyles of its Upper-class Victorians.  Emma Thompson won the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay, and it's easy to see why, with great, enjoyable dialogue and a great sense of character and thematic development. If you don't like Jane Austen and Austen-like films (i.e. half of the period dramas that came after this highly influential movie), then you probably won't like this, but it's great for everyone else; a nice, pleasant, genuine piece of escapism.

There's a lot to be said about the popularity of classic English romance. Having never watched more than 20 seconds of Downton Abbey, I can't rightly say that I'm a fan of the genre. I enjoy European films about class, but when the main focus is romance all I see are uptight, overdressed people being silly about their station. It's far more interesting to criticize the objectification of love than to pretend there was any romance during the Romantic Period. While this movie has much wit, I don't see any moral lesson that translates to the modern age.
While none of the main characters pass the Bechdel test, I imagine that's more a sign of the times than a bad script. The only way to move forward in that era was either as a wife or a spinster, so what's a girl to do? However, based on Jane Austen's reputation, I was expecting much more of a fight from these women. Why they fall in love with these men is not obvious, other than the fact they are threatened with poverty. Mr. Willoughby's a Manic Pixie Dream Boy who reads sonnets and snipping lox of hair, and his telegraphed downfall doesn't feel rewarding in any modern feminist context.
All that being said, I still found this movie is well written, well acted, well directed, and beautifully designed. Much of the imagery by director Ang Lee evokes memories of oil painted vistas and still-life fruitbowls. The tales is a game of rules and manners; agreements and dishonesty; pheasants and terriers; and it is skillfully crafted. But add all that together what do we have? A story about class struggle that is too frivolous to be truly great.

As a ginormous fan of Jane Austen, I tried twice but just could not finish this movie.  I realize that I'm probably in the minority; but Emma Thompson, in my opinion, just took too many liberties with the script, deviating a little too much not only from the content of the original novel, but more importantly from its spirit.

And this, again in my view, had much to do with the casting.  I love Emma Thompson as an actor; but she was (and I hate to voice this)-- she was simply too old to play the part of Elinor Dashwood.  Furthermore, Kate Winslet, whom I also respect very much as an actor, was miscast as Marianne Dashwood, capturing neither the magnetism nor volatility of the character-- and hence was not as central within the movie as the book.  She seemed more a secondary, supporting presence in the shadow of Elinor; but the real 'love story' within the book is that between the two sisters, whose individual strengths and weaknesses, and ultimately unconditional love for one another, helps both to endure and even grow through very difficult challenges.  And for this to be delineated, Marianne must have a very strong presence in the story, which seemed lacking for me in the movie.

Continuing in my picky-ness, Hugh Grant, who would have made a perfect Willoughby, was woefully miscast as Edward Ferrars.  And I have other complaints about the casting, though I am reaching perhaps a point of embarrassment at just how picky I must seem by now ...

Probably the lesson for me here is that when I watch movies adapted from favorite authors or novels, they just might not go quite as I would have had them!  lol

Before there was "Price and Prejudice", there was "Sense and Sensibility", so I reckon Jane Austen was pretty big into catchy titles with "and" in them early on in her career, as surely as Kate Winslet was pretty big into coming-of-age period dramas early on in her career. I don't know about you people, but I got pretty nervous watching this film, as Winslet was fresh off of the set of the period psychological thriller "Heavenly Creatures", and you know what we got in that coming-of-age opus: ...a really bad movie. Winslet's character was pretty crazy in that film, and Peter Jackson was probably even crazier for making the film, but hey, at least this film is decent, which I reckon means that the more overlong and British the period drama featuring Kate Winslet is, the better it ends up being, as Winselt would go on to remind us in that awesome, four-hour-long and outstandingly British "Hamlet" in '96. Well, then again, "Titanic" is easily her best film, and the closest James Cameron has come to being British is being raised in a place that has a province called British Columbia, and plus, I don't see how this film can get any more British, as it's based on a Jane Austen book, is written by and stars Emma Thompson, also features Kate Winslet, Alan Rickman, Hugh Grant and Tom Wilkinson, and is directed by... some Taiwanese dude. Hey, the next film interpretation of "Sense and Sensibility" was some Indian musical, so I guess this book is pretty popular in Asia, but then again, "Kandukondain Kandukondain" is a loose adaptation of this novel, much like most every other post-1995 interpretation of "Sense and Sensibility", so this novel couldn't be too popular, or else it would have been adapted, like, 87 times like every other popular, classic dramatic novel of this nature. Hey, this film was such a hit that maybe people didn't want to touch the novel upon which it's based anymore because they knew they could never hope to top it. Ang Lee knows how to get things done, except maybe when it comes to "Hulk", though I can't say that I'm nearly as crazy about this film as everyone else seems to be, and quite a few reasons.

This type of period drama's is a formula that has been done to death throughout the years, and although we've kind of gotten a bit used to it over time, and although there are some relatively refreshing beats to this particular effort, there's no ignoring the conventionalism to this paint-by-numbers coming-of-age period drama dealing with a young lady trying to defy tradition to take the hand of a man she feels genuine love for, nor is there any denying that this film takes a bit too long of a time to tell such a familiar story. I suppose this film's subject matter warrants something of a hefty length, as there have been decidedly lengthier interpretations of Jane Austen's three-volume lady drama "epic", yet whether it be from the lengthy source material or from Emma Thompson's pen, there is much fat around the edges, and they guide the final product to its 136-minute length through aimless filler and repetition that are detrimental to pacing enough of paper, clean of Ange Lee's questionable atmospheric influences. As often as I have been impressed with Lee's storytelling, he has a tendency to incorporate into his film the type of dryness this very formal drama apparently demands, and sure, Lee has proven that he has the impressive ability to put such atmospheric limpness to very good use, yet the fact of the matter is that this film, on top of being bloated, gets to be chilled quiet meandering spells that prove to be bland more often than not, and sometimes prove to be downright dull. There's enough cleverness to Lee's usage of the atmosphere to keep things from getting all that boring, but the quiet coldness in this film proves to be about as supplementary to the limp pacing as it proves to be complimentary to the dry color of this formal fluff piece, which could have stood as rewarding through all of its limp spells if it wasn't so much of what I just said it is: a fluff piece. Nevermind the conventionalism of a story of this type, Austen's source material just doesn't have a whole lot of meat or consequence to its conflicts, being sharp and all, but with too much minimalism for it to appear to be something that could easily be made into the rewarding opus that this film is sadly not sharp enough to be. That being said, the film is carried almost to a rewarding state on the shoulders of endearing charm, backed by plenty of genuinely commendable strengths, but you're given too much to think about the natural shortcomings of this minimalist and formulaic drama by overdrawn cold spells for underwhelmingness to be kept at bay. Regardless, the final product is quite enjoyable, being seriously flawed, but competent enough areas to entertain adequately, and do so with a tastefulness that can even be found clear as day within the musical aspects.

I've always found Patrick Doyle to be a rather underappreciated and excellent score composer who may not boast too much originality to his musical visions, but has an exceptional classical style that breathes a lot of life into his projects, including this one, for although the many quiet spells of this film silence Doyle's efforts in more places than it should, when the music finally kicks back in, it's hard not to be particularly engrossed, as Doyle bonds very 19th century elegance and relatively modernist fluffiness within a thoroughly colorful classical score that proves to be hauntingly beautiful and highly complimentary to the establishment of a feel for the era portrayed in this classical period piece. Needless to say, an even more recurring and thorough component to the immersion value of this period piece is Philip Elton's and Andrew Sanders' exceptional art direction, which, with the help of Luciana Arrighi's intricate production designs and Jenny Beavan's and John Bright's costume designs, restores the Georgian era of England with a subtly detailed eye that catches your eye and thrusts you into a distinguished world, but not without being down-to-earth enough to thoroughly convince. Very tasteful and clever with its celebration of lovely music and lively production value, this fairly well-produced film is at least rewarding on an artistic level, immersing you into the setting of this period piece, while the acting helps in immersing you into the depths of the more human aspects of this drama. There is, of course, very little in the way of heavy dramatic material for this talented cast to play with, and without that kind of acting demand which keeps the performers alert, acting in films of this nature usually fail to hold enough inspiration for you to look at the characters as anything more than types, yet in this case, while the performances aren't outstanding, most everyone makes sure to make his or her character particularly memorable through colorfully distinguished charisma that sells you on the characters, while excellent chemistry sells you on the relationships that define the characters and their story. Disregarding the occasional emotionally powered dramatic note, the performers aren't exactly able to anchor the dramatic punch that could have made this film truly rewarding, but they do carry many aspects of this fairly human character piece, though cannot be enough to bring the final product close to a rewarding level. What truly secures the considerable decency and borderline bona fide goodness of this film, is, of course, the storytelling, or at least the highlights within the formulaic, overlong and dry storytelling, such as a cleverness to Emma Thompson's score that captures the wit of Jane Austen's classic novel, but settles down the romanticism enough for you to connect a bit to the sharp dialogue and humor, often in an amusing way, resulting in a fair degree of color that director Ang Lee augments, at least up to a point, as his dry atmosphere all too often blands things up, but is just as often appropriate enough for a formal fluff piece of this type for you to soak up the cold color that defines the endearing charm of this period drama. If the film is nothing else, it is thoroughly charming, and while that's certainly not enough to make a strong film, it certainly deserves credit for bringing the film close to a rewarding state, joining tasteful artistic value and good acting in making the final product reasonably entertaining, if improvable.

Overall, the film tells a formulaic tale, and does so in an overlong, repetitious fashion that is made all the more relatively grating by a bland atmospheric dryness which leaves you to meditate upon the inconsequentiality of this drama, which ultimately sputters out as underwhelming, but just barely, being supported enough by a loveliness to music, immersive intricacy to cinematography, charisma to acting, and dry color to sharp writing and direction for Ang Lee's "Sense and Sensibility" to stand as a pretty enjoyable, if held back interpretation of a Jane Austen classic.
